div1.head: Military Orders for Walter Reed, Jefferson Randolph Kean, Alexander N. Stark, September 28, 1900
div1.p:
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Spec Orders Vol 2
1900

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, September 28, 1900.

1. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Private
Robert Sanderson, Company H, 2d Infantry, recruiting station,
No. 514 West Jefferson street, Louisville, Kentucky, will be
discharged without honor from the Army by the officer in
charge of that station, by reason of desertion. This soldier is
not entitled to travel-pay.

2. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Privates
Clarence A. Chute, Troop A, 4th Cavalry; Edward F. Maloney,
Company B, 4th Infantry; Corporal Harry J. Walker, Com-
pany E, 9th Infantry; Privates Robert E. Gordon, Company F,
20th Infantry; John H. Bonzey and John Gillies, Company K,
21st Infantry, Army General Hospital, Presidio of San Fran-
cisco, California, will be sent to the Army and Navy General
Hospital, Hot Springs, Arkansas, reporting upon arrival to the
commanding officer for treatment in the hospital. The com-
manding officer of the hospital at the Presidio of San Fran-
cisco will forward by mail to the commanding officer of the
hospital at Hot Springs the descriptive lists and accounts of
pay and clothing of the soldiers. Unless these soldiers are
proper subjects for discharge for disability or change of cli-
mate, the commanding officer of the hospital will on conclu-
sion of treatment send them to their proper stations, as re-
quired by Circular, No. 16, of December 8, 1892, from this
office.

3. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Recruit
Robert E. Elam, general service, now at Columbus Barracks,
Ohio, having enlisted under false pretences, will be discharged
without honor from the Army by the commanding officer of
his station. Under paragraph 1386 of the Regulations this
soldier is not entitled to travel-pay and final statements shall
not be furnished him.

4. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Private
Arthur Milthorp, Hospital Corps, now at the Hospital Corps
school of instruction, Fort McDowell, California, is relieved
from further duty in the Division of the Philippines and will
5
Engineers, in Special Orders, No. 173, September 18, 1900, U.S.
Military Academy, is extended twenty-three days.

22. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, a board of
officers to consist of--

Major Walter Reed, surgeon, U. S. Army;
✓

Major Jefferson R. Kean, surgeon, U. S. Volunteers;
✓

Captain Alexander N. Stark, assistant surgeon, U. S. Army,
is appointed to meet at Columbia Barracks, Quemados, Cuba,
on Monday, October 22, 1900, for the examination of such offi-
cers of the Medical Department as may be ordered before it
to determine their fitness for promotion. The junior officer
will act as recorder, and the professional examinations will be
conducted under such special instructions as the board may
receive from the Surgeon General of the Army, through whom
the reports of the board will be forwarded to the Adjutant
General of the Army.
✓

23. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, 1st Lieu-
tenant John H. Stone, assistant surgeon, U. S. Army, will
report in person on Monday, October 22, 1900, to Major Walter
Reed, surgeon, U. S. Army, president of the examining board
appointed to meet at Columbia Barracks, Quemados, Cuba,
by Special Orders, No. 228, September 28, 1900, from this office,
for examination as to his fitness for promotion, and upon the
completion thereof will return to his proper station. The
travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

24. By direction of the President, under the provisions of
the act of Congress approved November 3, 1893, MajorJohn
C. Scantling, 2d U. S. Artillery, upon his own application is
detailed by the Acting Secretary of War as professor of mili-
tary science and tactics at the Maryland Agricultural College,
College Park, Maryland, to take effect October 1, 1900, the
date of his retirement from active service.

25. By direction of the Secretary of War, George W. Chit-
tenden, late private, Company M, 6th Infantry, a general
prisoner now at Alcatraz Island, California, under sentence
of imprisonment for twenty (20) years (Special Orders, No.
36, headquarters, Department of Visayas, Philippine Islands,
May 23, 1900), will be transferred under proper guard to the
United States penitentiary at Fort Leavenworth, Kansas, for
the completion of his sentence.
BY COMMAND OF LIEUTENANT GENERAL MILES:
